minor.title: Minor Skill Deficit
minor.mentality: This minor gap means you're climbing well, but with some small refinements to your technique and strategy, you can unlock your next grade.

routines.name: Constraint Drills
routines.description: Force yourself to be more precise and break sloppy habits by adding a rule to your climbing on terrain you know well.
routines.protocol: Choose a climb 2-3 grades below your max and try it with a constraint like: 1) 'Silent Feet': No noise on foot placements. 2) 'No Readjusting': Once a hand or foot is placed, it cannot be moved.

routines.name: Video Analysis
routines.description: The camera is an honest coach. Film yourself on attempts at your limit to spot inefficiencies you can't feel while climbing.
routines.protocol: Record your attempts and pay close attention to your body position, pacing, and hip movement. Compare it to videos of more experienced climbers on a similar style.

moderate.title: Moderate Skill Deficit
moderate.mentality: There is a clear disconnect between your physical strength and your climbing grade. This is great newsâ€”it means your fastest path to improvement is by focusing on skill. Your priority should be deliberate, on-the-wall practice.

routines.name: Movement Library Day
routines.description: Dedicate an entire session to one or two specific climbing techniques. The goal is not to send hard, but to understand and execute fundamental movements correctly.
routines.protocol: Pick a theme for the day (e.g., 'Drop-Knees' or 'Heel Hooks'). Find 5-6 different problems that require this move and work on them exclusively.

routines.name: Tactical Application
routines.description: Improve your ability to read a route and conserve energy before you even touch the wall.
routines.protocol: Before getting on a new climb, stand back and visualize the entire sequence. Mime the moves and articulate your plan. The goal is to climb smarter, not just harder.

major.title: Major Skill Deficit
major.mentality: You have a massive strength foundation, but you're leaving a lot of potential on the table due to inefficient movement. Your #1 focus should be a 'back-to-basics' approach to rebuild your technique. Place your strength training on maintenance (1x per week) and become a student of movement.

routines.name: The Mileage Reset
routines.description: You need to unlearn bad habits by ingraining good ones through high volumes of easy climbing where you can focus entirely on perfect form.
routines.protocol: For the next 4 weeks, spend 80% of your climbing time on routes 3-4 V-grades below your max. The goal is to climb a huge number of problems with fluid, beautiful technique.

routines.name: Become a Slab & Vertical Specialist
routines.description: You are likely avoiding the climbs that would teach you the most. These styles cannot be solved with brute force and are honest teachers of balance and precision.
routines.protocol: Dedicate at least one full session per week exclusively to slab and technical vertical climbs. Embrace the struggle; this is where your growth lies.

minor.title: Minor Finger Strength Weakness
minor.mentality: Your finger strength is slightly lagging, but it doesn't require a massive overhaul of your training. You can address this with supplemental work that fits around your regular climbing.

routines.name: Post-Session Hangboard
routines.description: A short, low-volume hangboard session done at the end of your climbing session to provide a targeted stimulus without requiring a separate day.
routines.protocol: After your climbing session, rest briefly, then perform 3-4 sets of 10-second hangs on a 20mm edge. Rest 2-3 minutes between sets.

routines.name: Targeted Bouldering
routines.description: Dedicate one of your weekly bouldering sessions to intentionally working on your weakness by choosing appropriate climbs.
routines.protocol: During one session per week, ensure at least 50% of your climbing is on routes that are crimpy or feature the small holds you want to improve on.

moderate.title: Moderate Finger Strength Weakness
moderate.mentality: This is a clear bottleneck that is holding you back. Addressing it requires a dedicated and consistent training stimulus. This should become a standard part of your weekly schedule.

routines.name: Max Hangs Protocol
routines.description: This is the gold standard for building raw finger strength. It requires a dedicated session after a thorough warm-up.
routines.protocol: Perform 5-6 sets of 10-second hangs on a 20mm edge. Rest 3 minutes between sets. The hold/weight should be challenging enough that you could only hang for ~13 seconds if you went to failure. Do this twice a week.

routines.name: Strength-Endurance (Repeaters)
routines.description: Use this if you struggle with sequences of multiple hard moves, not just a single hard grip.
routines.protocol: Perform a set of hangs consisting of 7 seconds on, 3 seconds off, repeated 6 times. This is one set. Rest 3-5 minutes and perform a total of 3-4 sets.

major.title: Major Finger Strength Weakness
major.mentality: This is your primary physical limiter. Fixing it should be your highest training priority. This calls for a focused and intense plan.

routines.name: Focused Strength Block (Weighted Hangs)
routines.description: For a weakness this significant, you likely need to add weight to your hangs to continue driving adaptation. This should be the focus of a 4-6 week training block.
routines.protocol: Use a weight belt or vest to add weight to your Max Hangs. Find a weight that makes a 10-second hang feel very challenging. Perform 5 sets, twice a week. Be extra vigilant about perfect form and listening to your body.

minor.title: Minor Pulling Strength Weakness
minor.mentality: Your overall power is good, but you could benefit from some supplemental work to improve your pulling endurance and lock-off strength on steeper climbs.

routines.name: Post-Session Pulls
routines.description: Build pulling endurance without requiring a separate training day.
routines.protocol: After your climbing session, perform 3 sets of pull-ups to about 80% of your max reps. Rest 3 minutes between sets.

routines.name: On-the-Wall Lock-offs
routines.description: Practice static strength in a more climbing-specific way.
routines.protocol: Find a steep wall with good holds. Practice holding a 'lock-off' position with your arm bent at 90 degrees for 5-10 seconds. Do this several times on each arm.

moderate.title: Moderate Pulling Strength Weakness
moderate.mentality: Your ability to execute powerful moves is a clear bottleneck. Building your pulling strength requires dedicated, consistent work and should be a scheduled part of your training.

routines.name: Weighted Pull-ups Protocol
routines.description: The most effective way to build raw pulling strength and make bodyweight pulls feel easier.
routines.protocol: After a full warm-up, perform 5 sets of 5 reps of weighted pull-ups. Choose a weight that makes the last rep of each set very difficult but possible with good form. Do this twice a week.

major.title: Major Pulling Strength Weakness
major.mentality: Your lack of pulling power is a primary factor preventing you from reaching the next level on steep or dynamic climbs. This requires an aggressive, high-priority training plan.

routines.name: Focused Pulling Block
routines.description: Dedicate 4-6 weeks to a pulling strength phase. Train it twice a week, focusing on both max strength and power.
routines.protocol: Session 1 (Max Strength): Heavy weighted pull-ups in the 3-5 rep range. Session 2 (Power): Bodyweight pull-ups performed as explosively as possible for 5-6 sets of 3-5 reps.
